AttributeValuesData.AttributeValue: The Jack Pine is North America's only northern, 2-to-a-bundle, short-needled pine. In fact, it is the most northerly New World Pinus species, reaching within 250 miles of the Arctic Ocean, and is the only only tree for vast stretches across northern Canada. Jack Pine is a small, somewhat scraggly tree; it colonizes poor-quality, upland soils, including recently-burned lands. Young pure Jack Pine stands provide the only nesting site for the endangered Kirtland's warbler. A notable characteristic of this tree is that the cones often bulge on one side.
Thin, reddish brown to gray on young stems, becoming dark brown and flaky; on old trunks furrowed into irregular thick plates

1 1/4 to 2" long, red-brown, asymmetrical, often bulging on one side and curved at the tip. In clusters of 2 or 3. Ovoid to narrowly ovoid when open, scales thick at tip, with delicate prickle. Cones upon at maturity, fire cones remain closed on tree for up to 20 years, opening from heat of fire.
In pairs, persisting 2 to 4 years, olive green, stiff, curved or slightly twisted, 3/4 to 2" long, margin with minute or rudimentary teeth, apex short-petiole, stomata on each surface
Short, stiff, olive green needles (to 1.5” long) in bundles of two, its strongly-curved cones (to 2.5” long) and its ability to grow in poor soils

ThemeEntityData.Description: The Jack Pine is North America's only northern, 2-to-a-bundle, short-needled pine. In fact, it is the most northerly New World Pinus species, reaching within 250 miles of the Arctic Ocean, and is the only only tree for vast stretches across northern Canada. Jack Pine is a small, somewhat scraggly tree; it colonizes poor-quality, upland soils, including recently-burned lands. Young pure Jack Pine stands provide the only nesting site for the endangered Kirtland's warbler. A notable characteristic of this tree is that the cones often bulge on one side.
